awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Trans-esterified Lignin Thermoplastic
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project addresses the need for affordable compostable plastics to replace petroleum-based plastics.  Plastic bags are an environmental eyesore that pollute waterways and kill wildlife.  Local governments are now passing laws to ban the use of plastic bags in efforts to hinder the spread of pollution.  The U.S. plastic bag market was over $10.6 billion in 2013.  While society and government have placed more emphasis on diverting compostable waste (25% to 40% of garbage) from landfills, the average American throws away 1,500 pounds of garbage every year.  Lignin output is expected to increase in the ensuing years due to an increase in lignin extraction plants coming on-line.  These modified lignin resins range in lignin concentration depending on the application.  Utilizing compostable lignin resins eliminates plastic waste and makes composting easier.  Using compostable bags and liners removes the risk of plastic contamination.  The objectives for this project include the determination of ideal production conditions for modified lignins and the creation of formulations for a variety of applications.  The commercialization of these modified lignins will help to alleviate the plastic waste problems that are impacting municipalities across the country.

The objectives of this research are to optimize production of chemically modified lignin and thermoplastics, develop quality control methods for raw lignin and modified lignin, and create more proprietary formulations to expand lignin applications.  Modified lignins were successfully produced in large scale during the Phase I project.  Phase II will continue to improve and expand the modified lignin production by optimizing for physical properties and cost.  The variables selected for this optimization include reaction time, reagent quantity, and reaction temperature.  Developing a continuous process is also an objective for this effort.  Compounding of modified lignin with other thermoplastics will also be optimized for physical properties and cost.  The variables for this portion include screw design, screw speed, and temperature.  Quality control methods for raw lignin and modified lignin will be developed using existing analytical methods tailored to the specifics of raw lignin and modified lignin.  In addition, formulations will be expanded to tailor blends to specific applications.  Strength, elongation, modulus, and cost are a few of the factors that determine what formulation should be used for a particular application.  The anticipated results of this Phase II project are to optimize the production process and produce consistent modified lignin.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The goal for this Small Business Innovation Research Phase 2 project was the development of lignin-based thermoplastics.  Lignin is the second most abundant natural biopolymer in the world, second only to cellulose.  It is also a byproduct of the paper manufacturing and biorefinery processes.  Lignin can be used to replace conventional petroleum-based plastics, and it has the benefits of biodegradability and compostability.  It also costs less than other biodegradable plastic alternatives.

The most important objective of Phase 2 research was the scaling and commercialization of a lignin derivative, hydroxypropyl lignin (HPL), for thermoplastic applications.  cycleWood has accomplished this goal, producing commercial tonnage scale batches of HPL.  The thermoplastic applications targeted for this HPL were compostable blown film and injection molded plastic applications.  cycleWood has successfully introduced consumer compostable trash bags, Xylobags (see image), to the market in 13-gallon and 33-gallon bag sizes.  Additionally, cycleWood has partnered with a pet products company to introduce a line of consumer compostable pet waste pickup bags to the market.  Additional trials are ongoing for injection molded products such as golf tees, shopping baskets, and cutlery.  cycleWood’s Phase 2 work resulted in improved product consistency and quality, as well as potential alternative manufacturing methods.  While great progress was made, cycleWood was unable to complete the full scope of the proposed Phase 2 work due to an acquisition of cycleWood’s technology.  The acquiring company is focusing all cycleWood resources towards growing the lignin derivatives market by selling and marketing existing products and resins.

cycleWood’s, Phase 2 research comprised a range of technical challenges involved in commercializing novel lignin-containing thermoplastics.  In addition to the aforementioned consumer products, some of cycleWood’s Phase 2 accomplishments and results are as follows:

  1. HPL production was scaled to a 5,000-gallon reactor producing 3 tons of HPL per batch.  This was done with standard stainless steel jacketed reactors, filter presses, and dryers.  If a manufacturing facility has the proper equipment and materials, cycleWood technology can be implemented in as little as two weeks. 
  2. Standard formulations were developed for injection molded and compostable blown film applications.  Compostable blown film formulations have been implemented in consumer products.  Injection molded formulations are currently being trialed for commercial applications.
  3. A neat reactive extrusion process was developed and showed potential as an alternative production method for lignin derivatives.  While not completely successful, the process showed that lignin can be chemically modified in an extruder.
  4. An alternative lignin thermoplastic, polycaprolactone modified lignin (Pcap lignin), was developed through a feasible process.  This alternative may be less expensive to produce and work better for some plastic applications.
  5. We were able to identify malodorous components of kraft lignin and implement a heating process to mitigate these components.  A fortuitous benefit of the slurry heating process was a reduction in filtering and washing time.
  6. An inexpensive analytical method was developed to determine the degree of lignin modification.  The method uses an inexpensive spectrometer and can be implemented at most manufacturing facilities.  A standard operating procedure was created as a reference for manufacturers.

 As a raw material, lignin presents a great opportunity.  It has the potential to displace or replace a significant amount of plastics produced from fossil fuels.  cycleWood’s technology proves that lignin is a feasible alternative.  With the support of the National Science Foundation and investors cycleWood has realized the commercialization of the first lignin-based consumer product.

 


Last Modified: 11/03/2016
Modified by: Nhiem H Cao

Image
  • 33 gallon Xylobags
    Nhiem Cao
    Nhiem H Cao
    Xylobags
